message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is specifically associated with t(15;17) translocation and the resulting PML/RARalpha fusion gene. None of the other translocations and fusion genes listed are associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation which results in the fusion gene PML/RARalpha. Option (B) is the correct answer. Option (A) is associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia, Option (C) is associated with follicular lymphoma, and option (D) is associated with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is characterized by the presence of t(15;17) which causes the fusion of PML (promyelocytic leukemia protein) and RARalpha (retinoic acid receptor alpha) genes. None of the other options are associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with t(15;17) translocation, which leads to the fusion of PML and RARalpha genes. None of the other translocations and fusion genes listed are associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with anemia and thrombocytopenia, which are commonly seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The translocation t(15;17) is seen in 95% of cases of APL and results in the fusion gene PML/RARalpha. The other translocations and fusion genes listed are not associated with APL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL) is associated with the t(15;17) translocation, which leads to the fusion gene PML/RARalpha. Thus, option (B) is the correct answer. Option (A) is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia, option (C) is associated with follicular lymphoma, and option (D) is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia with the Philadelphia chromosome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with the t(15;17) translocation and fusion gene PML/RARalpha. This results in abnormal maturation of myeloid cells and may lead to bleeding, infections, and even death. The other translocations and fusion genes mentioned are associated with other types of leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with t(15;17) translocation and PML/RARalpha fusion gene. None of the other options are associated with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation and the resulting PML/RARα fusion gene. None of the other translocations and fusion genes listed are associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, which results in the fusion of PML and RARalpha genes. None of the other options are associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia.
